bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Burton J. Hendrick, April 15, 1924

div1.p: Kean expresses doubt that the statements already published in the excerpts of Gorgas' biography can be corrected in the final publication without contradiction.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Burton J. Hendrick, April 15, 1924
div1.opener:
JRK/FM
15 April 1924.
Mr. Burton J. Hendrick,
Editor, World's Work,
Garden City, N.Y.
My dear Mr. Hendrick:
div1.p:
I have your very prompt and courteous reply of
April 14th and regret to note that you say nothing about
publishing my corrective statement. Also, it is not clear
to me how the full chapter as it will be published in the
book can correct the erroneous statements in the chapter
as published in the World's Work without making conflict-
ing statements.

It is a pleasure to know that Dr. Henry R. Carter
is reviewing the manuscript and I would be glad to have him
read my corrective statement. He is a brilliant and dis-
tinguished sanitary authority and thoroughly familiar with
the literature of yellow fever. Just how familiar he is
with the genesis of the work in Cuba, I do not know, but I
am sure that he will have an open mind in the matter.

I shall be glad to have you make use of my little
article in the way you suggest, but if there is to be no
publication of it in your magazine, it will be understood
that Mrs. Reed can make any use of it that she and her
friends desire. It was written at her request and should
be used as she thinks best in the interest of justice to
her husband.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J. R. Kean,
Colonel, M.C., U.S. Army.
